statement.p:
Consider the set of vectors
\vvec_1 = \threevec{1}{2}{1}, \vvec_2 = \threevec{0}{1}{3}, \vvec_3 = \threevec{2}{3}{-1}, \vvec_4 = \threevec{-2}{4}{-1} .
Explain why this set of vectors is linearly dependent.
Write one of the vectors as a linear combination of the others.
Find weights c_1, c_2, c_3, and c_4, not all of which are zero, such that c_1\vvec_1 + c_2 \vvec_2 + c_3 \vvec_3 + c_4 \vvec_4 = \zerovec .
Suppose A=\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\vvec_3\amp\vvec_4 \end{array}\right]. Find a nonzero solution to the homogenous equation A\xvec = \zerovec.

li.p: From the solution to the previous part, we have -2\vvec_1+\vvec_2+\vvec_3 = \zerovec, which says that c_1=-2, c_2=1, c_3=1, and c_4=0 is an appropriate choice of weights.
From the solution to the previous part, we see that \xvec = \fourvec{-2}{1}{1}{0} is a solution of the homogeneous equation.
Four vectors in \real^3 must always be linearly dependent.
\vvec_3 = 2\vvec_1-\vvec_2.

statement.p:
Consider the vectors
\vvec_1 = \threevec{2}{-1}{0}, \vvec_2 = \threevec{1}{2}{1}, \vvec_3 = \threevec{2}{-2}{3} .
Are these vectors linearly independent or linearly dependent?
Describe the \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3}.
Suppose that \bvec is a vector in \real^3. Explain why we can guarantee that \bvec may be written as a linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3.
Suppose that \bvec is a vector in \real^3. In how many ways can \bvec be written as a linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3?

li.p: Since the matrix has a pivot position in every row, we see that \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} = \real^3.
Because \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} = \real^3, every vector in \real^3 can be written as a linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3.
In exactly one way. Because the matrix has a pivot position in every column, there cannot be a free variable.
Linearly independent.
\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} = \real^3.
Because \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3} = \real^3, every vector in \real^3 can be written as a linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3.
In exactly one way.

statement.p:
Respond to the following questions and provide a justification for your responses.
If the vectors \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 form a linearly dependent set, must one vector be a scalar multiple of the other?
Suppose that \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n is a linearly independent set of vectors. What can you say about the linear independence or dependence of a subset of these vectors?
Suppose \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n is a linearly independent set of vectors that form the columns of a matrix A. If the equation A\xvec = \bvec is inconsistent, what can you say about the linear independence or dependence of the set of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n,\bvec?

li.p: Yes. If c_1\vvec_1 + c_2\vvec_2 = \zerovec and one of the weights is not zero, we can rearrange this expression to solve for one of the vectors as a scalar multiple of the other. For instance, if 2\vvec_1-3\vvec_2=\zerovec, then \vvec_1 = \frac32\vvec_2.

Any subset of the vectors forms a linearly independent set. Because the original set is linearly independent, none of the vectors can be written as a linear combination of the others. This is still true when we look at a smaller set of the vectors.

The set of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n,\bvec will also be linearly independent. Since A\xvec=\bvec is inconsistent, we know that \bvec cannot be written as a linear combination of the other vectors. We also know that each of the vectors \vvec_j cannot be written as a linear combination of the others because \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n is a linearly independent set.
Yes
Any subset is linearly independent.
They form a linearly independent set.

statement.p:
Determine whether the following statements are true or false and provide a justification for your response.
If \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n are linearly dependent, then one vector is a scalar multiple of one of the others.
If \vvec_1, \vvec_2, \ldots, \vvec_{10} are vectors in \real^5, then the set of vectors is linearly dependent.
If \vvec_1, \vvec_2, \ldots, \vvec_{5} are vectors in \real^{10}, then the set of vectors is linearly independent.
Suppose we have a set of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n and that \vvec_2 is a scalar multiple of \vvec_1. Then the set is linearly dependent.
Suppose that \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n are linearly independent and form the columns of a matrix A. If A\xvec = \bvec is consistent, then there is exactly one solution.

li.p: False. We only know that one vector can be written as a linear combination of the others.
True. If we put the vectors into a matrix, there are more columns than rows. Therefore, there must be a column without a pivot position so the vectors form a linearly dependent set.
False. They could form a linearly independent set, but we cannot guarantee it. We would have to look at the location of the pivot positions in the associated 10\times5 matrix.
True. In this case, \vvec_2 can be written as a linear combination of the other vectors so the set is linearly dependent.

True. Since the vectors are linearly independent, A has a pivot position in every column. Therefore, there is not a free variable in the description of the solution space to the equation A\xvec=\bvec. Therefore, the solution is unique.
False

statement.p:
Suppose we have a set of vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3,\vvec_4 in \real^5 that satisfy the relationship:
2\vvec_1 - \vvec_2 + 3\vvec_3 + \vvec_4 = \zerovec
and suppose that A is the matrix A=\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\vvec_3\amp\vvec_4 \end{array}\right] .
Find a nonzero solution to the equation A\xvec = \zerovec.
Explain why the matrix A has a column without a pivot position.
Write one of the vectors as a linear combination of the others.
Explain why the set of vectors is linearly dependent.

li.p: The vector \xvec=\fourvec{2}{-1}{3}{1} is a solution.

There is a nonzero solution to the homogeneous equation A\xvec=\zerovec. Since there is also the zero solution \xvec=\zerovec, there must be infinitely many solutions. This can only happen when there is a column of A that does not have a pivot position.
\vvec_4 = -2\vvec_1 + \vvec_2 - 3\vvec_3.
Because one of the vectors can be written as a linear combination of the others, the set of vectors is linearly dependent.
There are infinitely many solutions to the homogeneous equation A\xvec=\zerovec.
\vvec_4 = -2\vvec_1 + \vvec_2 - 3\vvec_3.
One vector can be written as a linear combination of the others.

statement.p:
Suppose that \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n is a set of vectors in \real^{27} that form the columns of a matrix A.
Suppose that the vectors span \real^{27}. What can you say about the number of vectors n in this set?
Suppose instead that the vectors are linearly independent. What can you say about the number of vectors n in this set?
Suppose that the vectors are both linearly independent and span \real^{27}. What can you say about the number of vectors in the set?
Assume that the vectors are both linearly independent and span \real^{27}. Given a vector \bvec in \real^{27}, what can you say about the solution space to the equation A\xvec = \bvec?

li.p: In this case, the matrix A must have a pivot position in evey row. There must be at least 27 vectors for this to be possible.
In this case, the matrix A must have a pivot position in every column. There must be at most 27 vectors for this to be possible.
There must be exactly 27 vectors.
There is exactly one solution to the equation A\xvec=\bvec because the matrix A has a pivot position in every row and every column.
There must be at least 27 vectors.
There must be at most 27 vectors.
There are exactly 27 vectors.
There is exactly one solution.

statement.p:

A set of 4 linearly independent vectors in \real^5.
A set of 4 linearly independent vectors in \real^4.
A set of 3 vectors whose span is \real^4.
A set of 5 linearly independent vectors in \real^3.

statement.p:
When we explored matrix multiplication in , we saw that some properties that are true for real numbers are not true for matrices. This exercise will investigate that in some more depth.
Suppose that A and B are two matrices and that AB = 0. If B \neq 0, what can you say about the linear independence of the columns of A?
Suppose that we have matrices A, B and C such that AB = AC. We have seen that we cannot generally conclude that B=C. If we assume additionally that A is a matrix whose columns are linearly independent, explain why B = C. You may wish to begin by rewriting the equation AB = AC as AB-AC = A(B-C) = 0.

li.p: Since B\neq0, there is a column of B, which we'll call \xvec, that is not zero. Since AB = 0, we know that A\xvec = \zerovec, which means that \xvec is a nonzero solution to the homogenous equation A\xvec = \zerovec. Therefore, the columns of A are linearly dependent.

Since the columns of A are linearly independent, the only solution to the homogeneous equation A\xvec=\zerovec is \xvec=\zerovec. Since that A(B-C) = 0, every column \xvec of B-C satisfies A\xvec = \zerovec. Therefore, every column of B-C is the zero vector, which implies that B=C.
They are linearly dependent.
The columns of B and C are all equal.

statement.p:
Suppose that k is an unknown parameter and consider the set of vectors
\vvec_1 = \threevec{2}{0}{1}, \vvec_2 = \threevec{4}{-2}{-1}, \vvec_3 = \threevec{0}{2}{k} .
For what values of k is the set of vectors linearly dependent?
For what values of k does the set of vectors span \real^3?

li.p: If the vectors span \real^3, there must be a pivot in the third row, which means that k\neq 3.
k\neq3.

statement.p:
Given a set of linearly dependent vectors, we can eliminate some of the vectors to create a smaller, linearly independent set of vectors.
Suppose that \wvec is a linear combination of the vectors \vvec_1 and \vvec_2. Explain why \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2, \wvec} = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}.
Consider the vectors
\vvec_1 = \threevec{2}{-1}{0}, \vvec_2 = \threevec{1}{2}{1}, \vvec_3 = \threevec{-2}{6}{2}, \vvec_4 = \threevec{7}{-1}{1} . Write one of the vectors as a linear combination of the others. Find a set of three vectors whose span is the same as \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3,\vvec_4}.
Are the three vectors you are left with linearly independent? If not, express one of the vectors as a linear combination of the others and find a set of two vectors whose span is the same as \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3,\vvec_4}.
Give a geometric description of \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3,\vvec_4} in \real^3 as we did in .

li.p:
If \wvec is a linear combination of \vvec_1 and \vvec_2, then we can write \wvec=a\vvec_1+b\vvec_2. Then any linear combination of \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\wvec can be rewritten as
c_1\vvec_1+c_2\vvec_2+c_3\wvec=(c_1+c_3a)\vvec_1 + (c_2+c_3b)\vvec_2\text{.}
The remaining three vectors are linearly dependent because \vvec_4 = 3\vvec_1+\vvec_2. We therefore have \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3,\vvec_4} = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}.
The vectors \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 are linearly independent so their span is a plane in \real^3.
Any linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \wvec can be rewritten as a linear combination of \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.
\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3,\vvec_4} = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_4}.
\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\vvec_3,\vvec_4} = \laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2}.
It is a plane in \real^3.
